Be a big boy and separate the issues Commissioner Goodell. They aren't relevant to one another. The 2010 "policy" prohibiting Sydney Seau to speak was NOT established as a precedent for future decisions & was meant to prohibit redundant information in speeches for posthumous inductees, thereby shortening the event for broadcasting purposes. The NFL owes EVERY HOF inductee the opportunity to be introduced by a loved one whether they are alive or not. Junior's daughter wants to honor her father & has no intentions of speaking negatively about the NFL during the induction ceremony. The legal aspects should be left to the courts. Junior gave everything he had to the sport and the NFL profited tremendously off of his dedication to football. Regardless of the concussion lawsuit or statements made by a player who was obviously fighting to keep his job, the Seau Family deserves to speak on behalf of their loved one who earned his way in to the NFL Hall of Fame by way of blood, sweat, tears & sacrifice unmatched by 99% of anyone who has ever played the game. The least you can do Commissioner Goodell, is allow Junior's daughter Sydney to speak on his behalf at the Hall of Fame ceremony on August 8th, 2015. Man up!

Be a big boy and separate the issues Commissioner Goodell. They aren't relevant to one another. The 2010 "policy" prohibiting Sydney Seau to speak was NOT established as a precedent for future decisions & was meant to prohibit redundant information in speeches for posthumous inductees, thereby shortening the event for broadcasting purposes. The NFL owes EVERY HOF inductee the opportunity to be introduced by a loved one whether they are alive or not. Junior's daughter wants to honor her father & has no intentions of speaking negatively about the NFL during the induction ceremony. The legal aspects should be left to the courts. Junior gave everything he had to the sport and the NFL profited tremendously off of his dedication to football. Regardless of the concussion lawsuit or statements made by a player who was obviously fighting to keep his job, the Seau Family deserves to speak on behalf of their loved one who earned his way in to the NFL Hall of Fame by way of blood, sweat, tears & sacrifice unmatched by 99% of anyone who has ever played the game. The least you can do Commissioner Goodell, is allow Junior's daughter Sydney to speak on his behalf at the Hall of Fame ceremony on August 8th, 2015. Man up!

Sydney Seau deserves to speak at her father's induction in to the the NFL Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio next month. Be a big boy and separate the issues Commissioner Goodell. They aren't relevant to one another. The 2010 "policy" prohibiting Sydney Seau to speak was NOT established as a precedent for future decisions & was meant to prohibit redundant information in speeches for posthumous inductees, thereby shortening the event for broadcasting purposes. The NFL owes EVERY HOF inductee the opportunity to be introduced by a loved one whether they are alive or not. Junior's daughter wants to honor her father & has no intentions of speaking negatively about the NFL during the induction ceremony. The legal aspects should be left to the courts. Junior gave everything he had to the sport and the NFL profited tremendously off of his dedication to football. Regardless of the concussion lawsuit or statements made by a player who was obviously fighting to keep his job, the Seau Family deserves to speak on behalf of their loved one who earned his way in to the NFL Hall of Fame by way of blood, sweat, tears & sacrifice unmatched by 99% of anyone who has ever played the game. The least you can do Commissioner Goodell, is allow Junior's daughter Sydney to speak on his behalf at the Hall of Fame ceremony on August 8th, 2015. Man up!

Sydney Seau deserves to speak at her father's induction in to the the NFL Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio next month. It was always Junior's wish to have his daughter speak at this ceremony & the NFL owes this honor to the Seau Family! “It’s frustrating because the induction is for my father and for the other players, but then to not be able to speak, it’s painful,” Sydney said. “I just want to give the speech he would have given. It wasn’t going to be about this mess. My speech was solely about him.”

This was my third, and likely last Bolt to the Q, regardless of whether the Chargers bolt from the Q. This was not a very well organized run. The Bolt to the Q has never been a crown jewel among local runs, but it's been fun and 'good enough' and unique so as to keep me coming back. Sadly, this year was just dreadful in my opinion (as far as races go, this is a first-world problem in the grand scheme of things of course, but since I paid for it, I'm going to vent). 
The 10K was poorly integrated, there was confusion about who was starting when, and where and how to line up. The giant long pen with one primary entrance at the rear (and not well marked) with a tiny unmarked 3 foot opening ahead of the 10K group, everything was just so poorly organized. I felt bad for the fast 10k'ers who then had to swim through the 5K walkers and don't get me started at having water stations at 1.5 and 2 miles. Really? Spacing out those water stations by a half mile? So very helpful.  Normally I wouldn't care but on such an unusually hot and muggy morning. Re-using the same water station for the out and back was pretty no bueno.
Ultimately, this one gave me the impression that the organizers were pretty much "well, this is the last one of these we'll be hosting so, save as much money as possible because it doesn't matter what impression we leave behind, we don't have to worry about a decline for next year's event since there won't be one. No offense to all the wonderful volunteers who put in their time, they did the best they could, it's the organizers that come off as highly questionable on this one.
It was awesome! Thank you to all the volunteers for the time you put into the event. So glad I flew in from Utah to participate and want to do it again next year.

Be a big boy and separate the issues Commissioner Goodell. They aren't relevant to one another. The 2010 "policy" prohibiting Sydney Seau to speak was NOT established as a precedent for future decisions & was meant to prohibit redundant information in speeches for posthumous inductees, thereby shortening the event for broadcasting purposes. The NFL owes EVERY HOF inductee the opportunity to be introduced by a loved one whether they are alive or not. Junior's daughter wants to honor her father & has no intentions of speaking negatively about the NFL during the induction ceremony. The legal aspects should be left to the courts. Junior gave everything he had to the sport and the NFL profited tremendously off of his dedication to football. Regardless of the concussion lawsuit or statements made by a player who was obviously fighting to keep his job, the Seau Family deserves to speak on behalf of their loved one who earned his way in to the NFL Hall of Fame by way of blood, sweat, tears & sacrifice unmatched by 99% of anyone who has ever played the game. The least you can do Commissioner Goodell, is allow Junior's daughter Sydney to speak on his behalf at the Hall of Fame ceremony on August 8th, 2015. Man up!

Sydney Seau deserves to speak at her father's induction in to the the NFL Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio next month. It was always Junior's wish to have his daughter speak at this ceremony & the NFL owes this honor to the Seau Family! “It’s frustrating because the induction is for my father and for the other players, but then to not be able to speak, it’s painful,” Sydney said. “I just want to give the speech he would have given. It wasn’t going to be about this mess. My speech was solely about him.”

Be a big boy and separate the issues Commissioner Goodell. They aren't relevant to one another. The 2010 "policy" prohibiting Sydney Seau to speak was NOT established as a precedent for future decisions & was meant to prohibit redundant information in speeches for posthumous inductees, thereby shortening the event for broadcasting purposes. The NFL owes EVERY HOF inductee the opportunity to be introduced by a loved one whether they are alive or not. Junior's daughter wants to honor her father & has no intentions of speaking negatively about the NFL during the induction ceremony. The legal aspects should be left to the courts. Junior gave everything he had to the sport and the NFL profited tremendously off of his dedication to football. Regardless of the concussion lawsuit or statements made by a player who was obviously fighting to keep his job, the Seau Family deserves to speak on behalf of their loved one who earned his way in to the NFL Hall of Fame by way of blood, sweat, tears & sacrifice unmatched by 99% of anyone who has ever played the game. The least you can do Commissioner Goodell, is allow Junior's daughter Sydney to speak on his behalf at the Hall of Fame ceremony on August 8th, 2015. Man up!
